channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Europe’s Been Negotiating by the Book, but Trump’s Tearing It Up
item.description: The Trump administration sees tariff talks as a chance to pressure a rival into concessions. E.U. officials have acted as though they were dealing with an ally.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Sean Gallup/Getty Images
item.media:description: Nearly $5 billion in goods and services cross the Atlantic between the United States and European Union every single day, by E.U. estimates.

item.title: In the Midst of War, a Tale of Hot Dogs
item.description: Nathan’s Famous has found a foothold in Ukraine, a hot dog-loving country.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alisa Dombrovska preparing a Nathan’s hot dog at the flagship store of the Ukrainian gas station chain Socar in Kyiv last month.

item.title: Hong Kong’s Famous Bamboo Scaffolding Hangs On (for Now)
item.description: Metal has begun to replace this distinctive latticework, which is seen on towers across the city. Daisy Pak, a rare female bamboo master, takes pride in the ancient craft.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Lam Yik Fei
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: How an Iconic Blouse Became the Center of a Political Tussle in Romania
item.description: Nationalists in Romania have adopted an item of clothing traditionally worn by villagers, particularly women. Liberals say it’s an appropriation of a cultural identity that belongs to everyone.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andreea Campeanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Embroidering traditional blouses this month in Domnesti, a village near the Romanian capital, Bucharest.

item.title: As Trump Demands More Military Spending, NATO Allies Reconsider What Counts
item.description: The president has long pressed European allies to pay more for their own security. So they may redefine what qualifies as security.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Sean Gallup/Getty Images
item.media:description: Lithuanian soldiers participating in NATO military exercises at an American facility in Hohenfels, Germany, in March.

item.title: In Attacks on Harvard, Chinese See Yet Another Reason to Write Off the U.S.
item.description: Beyond the shock for students, President Trump’s moves against higher education are being seen in China as a blow to one of the last admirable American institutions.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Mass., in April. American schools like Harvard have remained attractive to Chinese students, who were willing to overlook other concerns for the promise of a best-in-the-world education.

item.title: Syrians Rush to Preserve Remembrances of a Painful Revolution
item.description: Many in Syria want to enshrine remnants of their recent history, not only to remember it, but as a cautionary tale.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Preserving posters and banners from the uprising against the dictator Bashar al-Assad in the northwestern town of Kafranbel, Syria.

item.title: At an Uncertain Moment for Germany, Suddenly Boring Doesn’t Look So Bad
item.description: The small city of Bielefeld was once the butt of jokes for its blandness. Now it embodies the kind of stability Germans long for.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The main shopping street in Bielefeld, Germany, this week.

item.title: Knife Attack at Train Station in Hamburg, Germany, Wounds at Least 17
item.description: Four of the victims are in critical condition. The police say they believe a 39-year-old woman carried out the attack, for which no motive has yet been given.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson, Christopher F. Schuetze and Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Jonas Walzberg/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Forensic police officers investigating a railway platform in Hamburg, Germany, the site of a knife attack in which at least 17 people were injured on Friday.

item.title: Paris Court Convicts Eight in 2016 Robbery of Kim Kardashian
item.description: The reality TV star, who was held at gunpoint as jewelry worth millions was stolen from her, said she was satisfied by the ruling.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Leo Vignal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Kim Kardashian, center in black, was accompanied by her mother, Kris Jenner, after Ms. Kardashian testified in a Paris court earlier this month.

item.title: American Emigration to Britain Rises
item.description: New data from the U.K. government showed applications surged in the first three months of this year, which some analysts attributed to the political climate in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pedestrians crossing a bridge across the River Thames in London. Immigration lawyers said they had received an increasing number of inquiries in recent months from people in the United States about possibly relocating to Britain.

item.title: Ukraine and Russia Begin Largest Exchange of Prisoners of War
item.description: Each side reported that 390 of its people had been returned, and more swaps are expected this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olena Nehir with her husband, Oleksandr Nehir, a Ukrainian prisoner of war who was released from Russian captivity on Friday in the Chernihiv region of Ukraine.

item.title: Bangladesh’s Leader Threatens to Resign Over Election Pressure
item.description: Muhammad Yunus has struggled to navigate between the army, career politicians and the protest movement that overthrew the country’s authoritarian leader last year.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Muhammad Yunus at his temporary office at Jamuna State Guest House in Dhaka, last year.

item.title: South Africa Sets the Stage for Starlink Approval
item.description: A proposed regulatory change would allow Elon Musk’s satellite company and others like it to get a license without having to sell shares to Black South Africans.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Elon Musk at the White House in April.

item.title: Working Out
item.description: Reorganizing your week just might make it possible to reorient your relationship with time.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Canada’s Central Banker on Economic Turmoil and Diversifying Trade
item.description: We spoke with Tiff Macklem, the governor of the Bank of Canada, after a meeting of top economic policymakers in Alberta.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Cole Burston//Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Tiff Macklem, the governor of the Bank of Canada, said uncertainty over tariffs was freezing investment.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Exchange Air Assaults Amid Major Prisoner Swap
item.description: The hourslong raids, involving hundreds of drones, were a reminder that any diplomatic resolution to the conflict remains far off.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Thomas Peter/Reuters
item.media:description: An apartment building damaged during a drone attack in Kyiv on Saturday. The Ukrainian capital was the Russian air assault’s main target.

item.title: Teachers Protest in Mexico City Shuts Down Airport
item.description: Flights were briefly halted, delaying travel for thousands, as security forces swarmed into passenger terminals in an effort to assert order.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Henry Romero/Reuters
item.media:description: Protesters at Mexico City’s international airport blocking a terminal on Friday.

item.title: Trump Signs Executive Orders for Faster Build-Out of Nuclear Power Plants
item.description: Among a flurry of executive actions, Mr. Trump directed the nation’s nuclear safety regulator to speed up approvals for new reactors.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Megan Varner/Reuters
item.media:description: A cooling tower is seen at the nuclear-powered Vogtle Electric Generating Plant in Waynesboro, Ga.

item.title: Lebanon Moves to Disarm Palestinian Groups, a Test Run for Hezbollah
item.description: After war with Israel weakened Iran-backed militias across the Middle East, including the Lebanese group Hezbollah, Lebanon’s government has moved to assert its authority over armed groups.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Dayana Iwaza and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Mohamed Azakir/Reuters
item.media:description: At the Burj al-Barajneh Palestinian refugee camp in Beirut, Lebanon this week. More than 200,000 Palestinian refugees live in Lebanon, according to the United Nations agency that serves Palestinian refugees.

item.title: Sebastião Salgado, Acclaimed Brazilian Photographer, Is Dead at 81
item.description: Known for his powerfully impactful images of nature and the human condition, he was widely regarded as one of the most important documentary photographers of his time.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Kevin Scanlon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The photographer Sebastião Salgado in 2009.

item.title: Historic Shipwrecks Come to Light in the Great Lakes
item.description: With an underwater drone named Rhody, archaeologists are mapping some of the dozens of sunken vessels in Lake Ontario.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Nazaryan
item.media:credit: NOAA Office of National Marine Sanctuaries / OECI
item.media:description: The bow of the Phillip Becker, covered in quagga mussels.

item.title: Yuri Grigorovich Dead: Soviet Ballet Choreographer Was 98
item.description: Among the 20th century’s most significant choreographers, he led the Bolshoi Ballet for more than 30 years, creating epic ballets like “Spartacus.”
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert
item.media:credit: Nikolay Vinokurov/Alamy Live News
item.media:description: Yuri Grigorovich at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow in 2017. As the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet from 1964 to 1995, he reshaped late-Soviet-era dance.

item.title: Trump Threatens 50% Tariff on E.U. and 25% Tariff on Apple
item.description: The president threatened both Apple and the European Union with higher tariffs on Friday, saying trade talks with the Europeans had stalled.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, Jeanna Smialek and Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Volkswagen factory in Zwickau, Germany. President Trump had paused heavy tariffs on countries around the world until July, but he announced on Friday that he was recommending a 50 percent tariff on imports from the European Union.

item.title: How to Understand Trump’s Latest Deportation Tactics
item.description: This week saw a dramatic court showdown and a mysterious flight to Djibouti.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Juba international airport in South Sudan, last year.

item.title: In ‘Cancer Alley,’ a Battle Over Who Gets to Measure Air Pollution
item.description: Community groups are fighting an unusual Louisiana law that restricts how they use data from air-quality monitors, saying it violates free speech.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Bryan Tarnowski for The New York Times
item.media:description: A meeting of Rise St. James in 2023, a group leading an effort to use low-cost air pollution monitors.

item.title: New Studies Dismiss Signs of Life on Distant Planet
item.description: In April, astronomers said they had detected a possible signature of life on the exoplanet K2-18b. Now, three independent analyses discount the evidence.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: An artist’s concept of the exoplanet K2-18b, 120 light-years from Earth, whose atmosphere has been creating a stir in astronomical circles.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the Capital Jewish Museum in Washington yesterday.

item.title: Trump Confirms Attempted Deportation of Migrants to South Sudan
item.description: The deportees are stuck in Djibouti amid a legal fight over their expulsions. A lawyer for some of the men said she was concerned for their health and welfare.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz, Alan Feuer and Mattathias Schwartz
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump confirmed that a group of migrants from several countries were stuck in Djibouti on their way to being deported to South Sudan.

item.title: Cargo Ship Crashed Into Man’s Yard After Crewman Fell Asleep, Police Say
item.description: A retiree living along a Norwegian fjord woke up on Thursday morning because his neighbor was pounding on his door, telling him to look outside. The ship just missed his house.
item.dc:creator: Henrik Pryser Libell
item.media:credit: Jan Langhaug/NTB, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The bow of a cargo ship sits lodged into the ground beside a house in Byneset, Norway, on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. to Impose Sanctions on Sudan Over Use of Chemical Weapons
item.description: The State Department’s announcement comes months after U.S. officials found evidence that Sudan’s military had used chemical weapons against its paramilitary rival.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sudanese armed forces during a military demonstration outside the city of Omdurman last year.

item.title: Netanyahu Names Maj. Gen. David Zini as New Domestic Spy Chief
item.description: The appointment of Maj. Gen. David Zini to head Shin Bet, Israel’s domestic intelligence agency, still faces a fraught legal process.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ronen Zvulun
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu named Maj. Gen. David Zini as his pick to head Shin Bet, Israel’s domestic intelligence agency.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Two Israeli Embassy Staff Killed
item.description: Plus, books to look forward to.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the Capital Jewish Museum in Washington yesterday.

item.title: After More Than a Century in Skorts and Skirts, Ireland’s Camogie Allows Shorts
item.description: A committee vote on Thursday approved a measure that would allow players in the women’s sport to choose between shorts or skorts during official play.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Piaras Ó Mídheach/Sportsfile, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Niamh Hanniffy of Galway and Meabh Murphy of Cork wore skorts, the required uniform, during a final in Dublin last year.

item.title: Trump Makes False Genocide Claims. South Africans Respond With Humor.
item.description: The jokes mask a deep-seated anger over the legacy of apartheid and the inequality that many Black people say continues to define life in their country.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Zimasa Matiwane
item.media:credit: Phill Magakoe/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A mother and a daughter watching a television broadcast of a bilateral meeting between President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa and President Trump, at their home in Silverton, Pretoria, South Africa, on Wednesday.

item.title: G7 Finance Ministers Show Unity in Support of Ukraine Against Russia
item.description: Top economic officials avoided a condemnation of U.S. tariffs but committed to trying to reduce “economic policy uncertainty.”
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Cole Burston/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Finance ministers and central bankers of the Group of 7 nations continued to blame Russia for the war in Ukraine, despite some initial resistance from the United States at their meeting in Banff, Canada.

item.title: Who Is Julius Malema, the South African Politician in the White House Video?
item.description: President Trump surprised a South African delegation with a video montage of apartheid-era chants from Mr. Malema.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Joao Silva/The New York Times
item.media:description: Julius Malema, leader of the Economic Freedom Fighters party, voting for the national assembly speaker in Cape Town, South Africa, in 2024.

item.title: Shooting Outside D.C. Jewish Museum Is Part of Global Surge in Antisemitism
item.description: Groups that monitor hate crimes said the Hamas attack in 2023 and the subsequent war had helped fuel tens of thousands of anti-Jewish incidents globally, including cases of verbal abuse and violence.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: The entrance to the Capital Jewish Museum in Washington was cordoned off after the killing of two Israeli Embassy employees on Wednesday.

item.title: Simon Mann, Mercenary Who Sought to Overthrow African Ruler, Dies at 72
item.description: After Eton and a successful career in the British Army, he became the go-to guy for military coups, he said. The rewards (and risks) were enormous.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Chris Radburn/PA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Simon Mann in 2009, after being released from prison in Equatorial Guinea. He was the “most notorious and best paid mercenary of my generation,” he wrote in his memoir.

item.title: In Trump Era, Taiwan Defense Chief Says U.S. Still Is a Check on China
item.description: Wellington Koo says the Trump administration has a shared interest in security in the region, but Taiwan must also ready its own forces for asymmetric warfare.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien, Chris Buckley and Meaghan Tobin
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wellington Koo, Taiwan’s defense minister.

item.title: Ukraine Fires Hundreds of Drones at Russia, Moscow Says
item.description: One of the biggest barrages of the war targeted 10 Russian regions, including Moscow, according to the Ministry of Defense, but it was not clear how much damage the attack did.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova

item.title: Forest Loss Around the World Hit a Record in 2024
item.description: Forests around the world disappeared at a rate of 18 soccer fields every minute, a global survey found. Fires accounted for nearly half of the losses.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi and Harry Stevens
item.media:credit: Eraldo Peres/Associated Press
item.media:description: Fires spread through the Brasília National Park during the dry season last September in Brazil.

item.title: Inside a Harrowing, Hail-Damaged Flight: ‘We Thought It Was Our Last’
item.description: When an IndiGo flight from New Delhi ran into a severe hailstorm, a passenger described several terrifying minutes: “They were calling their gods, we were calling our gods.”
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Sheikh Samiullah
item.media:description: As passengers deplaned from the IndiGo jet, they noticed the plane’s nose was severely damaged from the hail.

item.title: Gaza Aid Deliveries Begin After Days of Delays
item.description: The U.N. said about 90 truckloads of supplies had begun to arrive at warehouses and other sites in the devastated territory. It was the first significant influx after a two-month Israeli blockade.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
item.media:credit: Eyad Baba/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Employees working inside a bakery in Deir el-Balah in the central Gaza Strip after Israel allowed limited humanitarian aid to enter the Palestinian territory on Thursday.

item.title: Kneecap Member Is Charged With Terror Offense Over Flag at London Concert
item.description: A member of the Northern Irish rap group Kneecap was accused of illegally displaying a flag in support of Hezbollah. Kneecap denied the offense.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Timothy O'Connell for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liam Og O Hannaidh, left, also known as Mo Chara, with fellow members of Kneecap last year.

item.title: Sarah Milgrim and Yaron Lischinsky Were Israeli Embassy Workers Killed in D.C. Shooting
item.description: Sarah Milgrim and Yaron Lischinsky met while working at the Israeli Embassy in Washington, her father said. Mr. Lischinsky had just bought an engagement ring, an official said.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon, Isabel Kershner and Natan Odenheimer

item.title: Kim Jong-un Vents Fury After Botched Launch of North Korean Destroyer
item.description: He vows to punish as criminals those responsible for the failure, in which the ship had its hull torn open and ended up on its side in the water.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Maxar Technologies, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A satellite image released by Maxar Technologies showed a new navy destroyer on Sunday, before its failed launch in Chongjin, North Korea.

item.title: Israelis, Stunned by D.C. Shooting, Fear Backlash Over Gaza War
item.description: Political leaders pointed fingers at each other, suggesting that their opponents were responsible for a rise in antisemitism and criticism of Israel.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers outside the Capital Jewish Museum in Washington early on Thursday.

item.title: UK Net Migration Almost Halved in 2024, Data Shows
item.description: Net migration dropped by 50 percent in 2024, data showed Thursday. So why was the prime minister warning of an “island of strangers” earlier this month?
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Kin Cheung/Associated Press
item.media:description: Passengers arriving at Heathrow Airport near London in 2023. The government estimated that net migration had dropped by almost half in 2024 compared to 2023.

item.title: South Africa Wanted to Talk Trade. Then Trump Turned Down the Lights.
item.description: In a bruising Oval Office meeting, the visitors’ plan to keep President Trump from focusing on false accusations of white genocide backfired spectacularly.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Ramaphosa and Mr. Trump during their meeting on Wednesday.

item.title: Alberta Separatism Push Roils Canada
item.description: The country is just emerging from a period of political turmoil with a new prime minister in place. But now Alberta, a conservative Western province, is planning a referendum to break away.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Amber Bracken
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trucks outside of Calgary, Alberta. The oil-rich province is home to a small but principled minority of separatists.

item.title: How ‘Daniel’ Led Our Reporters to an Assembly Line for Russian Spies
item.description: For years, Russia used Brazil as a launchpad for its most elite intelligence officers, known as illegals. They started businesses, made friends and had love affairs — events that, over many years, became the building blocks of entirely new identities. Jane Bradley and Michael Schwirtz, investigative reporters for The New York Times, discuss one case.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley, Michael Schwirtz, Christina Thornell, Laura Salaberry and Nikolay Nikolov

item.title: As the Soviet Union Fell, Did the K.G.B. Leave Behind a Gift in Brazil?
item.description: A forensic analysis of birth certificates used by deep-cover operatives suggests a tantalizing possibility.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: John van Hasselt/Sygma, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The K.G.B. headquarters in Moscow in 1982. The culture of Russian espionage often prizes creative long-term planning over immediate expediency.

item.title: Roof of 14th-Century Drum Tower Partially Collapses in China
item.description: The Drum Tower in Fengyang County, which dates to the 14th century, is one of many historical sites that have been renovated as cultural tourism has boomed.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Social media, via Reuters

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: A fraught White House meeting.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa and President Trump in the Oval Office yesterday.

item.title: Short of Prison Space, U.K. Will Adopt U.S. Model of Time Off for Good Conduct
item.description: The British government said criminals could earn earlier release under a new program to cut the prison population, citing Texas as an inspiration.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:credit: Andy Rain/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The Wandsworth prison in London, which a report found to be overcrowded and infested with vermin last year.

item.title: Trump Casts Himself as a Protector of Persecuted White People
item.description: President Trump publicly dressed down the president of South Africa based on a fringe conspiracy theory, providing a vivid distillation of his views on race.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald Trump met President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa in the Oval Office on Wednesday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Trump Lectures South Africa’s Leader
item.description: Plus, everyone is moving to Chengdu.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa and President Trump in the Oval Office, yesterday.

item.title: Don’t Mention Climate: Now, Clean Energy Is All About the Money
item.description: The Inflation Reduction Act was once hailed as the biggest climate law in U.S. history. But as supporters try to save it, they’ve stopped talking about the environment altogether.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Joe Buglewicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wind turbines at the New London State Pier in Connecticut, destined for the South Fork Wind Farm.

item.title: Republican Bill Could Set Off Global Tax Fight
item.description: Retaliatory taxes on foreign companies operating in the U.S. could open the door for a broader economic conflict.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: If Congress passes the sweeping tax legislation being pushed by Republicans, it is likely to become a more prominent source of tension between the United States and other nations.
